node.title: ‘It’s about time:’ Voters reflect on possibly electing N.Y.C.’s second Black mayor ever.
node.description: New York has had 109 mayors, only one of whom, David Dinkins, was Black. Many voters said Eric Adams’s likely victory felt personal.

node.title: High-Rise That Collapsed in Nigeria Was Supposed to Be 15 Floors, Not 21: Officials
node.description: The building collapse in Lagos killed at least 14 people and left dozens missing beneath the rubble.

node.title: Facebook to Delete Facial Recognition Data of a Billion Users Amid Privacy Concerns
node.description: "This change will represent one of the largest shifts in facial recognition usage in the technology's history," the company wrote in a blog post.

node.title: Pasta Machine Crushes 22 Bones in Chef's Hand in 'Excruciating' Accident
node.description: Milwaukee chef Suzzette Metcalfe feared she would lose her hand in the accident that left her fingers like "sausages that were boiled too long and burst open."

node.title: Third Giraffe Dies at Dallas Zoo in One Month, Officials Looking Into Potential 'Toxin'
node.description: "Currently, while we suspect the two deaths may be connected, we are still working toward definitive proof," zoo officials said in a statement.

node.title: Johnson & Johnson COVID Vaccine Recipients Almost 4X as Likely to Get Blood Clots: Study
node.description: The study also noted that women aged 30-49 showed the highest risk levels among all recipients counted.

node.title: Belching cows put Kiwi science on world stage at COP26
node.description: A tossed off comment from UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson about belching cows has put work by clever Kiwi scientists onto the world stage at COP26. Audio

node.title: U.S. sues to stop major book publisher merger
node.description: Government claims $2.2 billion combo to reshape book industry would in turn hurt authors and, ultimately, readers.

node.title: Facebook to shut down face-recognition system
node.description: The social network said it will end its face-recognition system and delete the face prints of more than 1 billion people.

node.title: Pfizer’s Covid vaccine could break sales records again next year.
node.description: For two years in a row, the company is on track to bring in more single-year revenue from the shots than any other medical product in history.

node.title: Covid shots for younger children could start days after a C.D.C. panel meets.
node.description: The Biden administration has enlisted 20,000 health workers and shipped 15 million doses ahead of the agency’s decision.

node.title: Woman Shot in Eye While Looking Through Apartment Peephole
node.description: Police are currently looking for a suspect although they said they don't believe the woman was the shooter's intended target.

node.title: NSW fast-tracks freedoms for fully vaccinated people
node.description: The NSW government is bringing forward new freedoms for fully vaccinated people and delaying privileges for those who've shunned the Covid-19 vaccine.

node.title: Coroner opens inquiry into death at Palmerston North Hospital
node.description: A coroner has opened an inquiry into the death of a mental health ward inpatient at Palmerston North Hospital over the weekend.

node.title: Speaker scraps isolation rules for MPs' return to Parliament
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is making plans to travel to Auckland early next week.

node.title: To Go Big, Sloppy Jane Went Underground
node.description: Four years ago, Haley Dahl dreamed of taking her band and an orchestra into a cave to record an album. The result, “Madison,” is out Friday.

node.title: Minneapolis will decide whether to replace its Police Department with a public safety agency.
node.description: By Mitch Smith and Tim Arango

node.title: Brad Lander is likely to beat a far-right Republican in the comptroller race.
node.description: The Republican nominee, Daby Carreras, is a longshot candidate who opposes vaccine mandates.

node.title: The Mark Zuckerberg Aesthetic
node.description: With his plans for a virtual reality metaverse, the Facebook founder pitches himself as a cultural impresario of the internet’s future.

node.title: Christian University Withdraws Invitation for Historian Over Planned Parenthood Ties
node.description: An online petition that racked up about 1,030 signatures by Tuesday morning spurred Samford University to cancel Jon Meacham's appearance.

node.title: American Woman Convicted of Killing Mother in Indonesia Headed Back to U.S
node.description: A women who helped put her dead mother's body into a suitcase was released from an Indonesian prison to return to the U.S.

node.title: Tesla loses $40B in value after Musk says Hertz deal not "signed yet"
node.description: Tesla's stock price fell 4% after CEO Musk tweeted that a reported deal to sell 100,000 cars to Hertz has not been finalized.

node.title: Donations to Boston’s mayoral candidates are coming from very different places.
node.description: Out-of-state donors have been more partial to the front-runner, Michelle Wu, while the city’s police officers have shown more support for Annissa Essaibi George.

node.title: Tupac Shakur Touring Exhibition Opens in January
node.description: The show, spearheaded by Shakur’s estate, will start out in Los Angeles. It’s “a story about race in America using Tupac as a proxy,” one of its producers said.

node.title: Facebook, Citing Societal Concerns, Plans to Shut Down Facial Recognition System
node.description: Saying it wants “to find the right balance” with the technology, the social network will delete the face scan data of more than one billion users.

node.title: Chinese Influencer Under Fire Over 'Wakanda Queen' Blackface Tutorial
node.description: The video received over 1 million likes on social media site Bilibili as the influnecer darkened her skin with black makeup and introduced herself as "Wakanda Queen."

node.title: What Does Aaron Rodgers, Other Athletes Getting Paid in Bitcoin Mean for Cryptocurrency?
node.description: "It transcends race, culture, border, profession, wealth and class," the Founder and CEO of Strike, a cryptocurrency trading application, told Newsweek.

node.title: CDC Weighing 'Monumental' Decision on Vaccine for Kids as Millions of Doses Shipped Out
node.description: The FDA has authorized emergency use of the Pfizer vaccine for children ages 5 to 11, but the CDC must sign off before widespread vaccinations can begin.

node.title: Biden Administration Plans to Sell Oil, Gas Leases Despite Climate Change Report
node.description: Despite a damaging report on fossil fuels released last week, the Biden administration plans to sell oil and gas leases despite a campaign pledge.

node.title: Israel’s energy minister could not access Monday talks in her wheelchair.
node.description: By Daniel Victor

node.title: Poll workers in New Jersey struggle to connect to the internet, causing delays.
node.description: The state is using e-poll books, as the tablet-like devices are called, for the first time in an election.

node.title: A prosecutor says Kyle Rittenhouse was ‘the only person who killed anyone’ in Kenosha unrest.
node.description: The trial began with a prosecutor portraying the teenager as a tourist who inserted himself into fiery unrest in Kenosha and initiated the confrontation that led him to shoot three men.

node.title: Pregnant Woman, Fetus Die After Doctors Wouldn't Perform Abortion Under Restrictive Law
node.description: A new restriction in Poland's abortion law prohibits abortions even in cases of congenital defects in the fetus.

node.title: China Accuses U.S. of Being Deliberately 'Vague' Over Nuclear Sub Accident
node.description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry accused the U.S. of lacking transparency a day after the U.S. Navy revealed more details about the October incident.

node.title: BP Reports $3.3B Profit as Soaring Gas Prices Hit Wallets Hard
node.description: Global consumers are witnessing a huge spike in oil and gas prices concerning people's bills in the coming months.

node.title: San Francisco Retailer Forced to Change Hours Due to Excessive Theft, Fourth Chain to Do So
node.description: San Francisco is ranked among the worst cities in the U.S. for retail crime, with store employees noting that the problem escalates at night.

node.title: Jetpack Man at LAX May Have Been 'Nightmare Before Christmas' Balloon
node.description: Video and photos of a Jack Skellington balloon flying in Los Angles last November may have provided one possible explanation for the jet pack sightings.

node.title: FDNY Denies Firehouse Closed Due to De Blasio Vaccine Mandate After Banner Draws Attention
node.description: Fire Commissioner Daniel Nigro blamed staffing shortages on people taking "bogus" sick leave because of New York City's vaccine mandate.

node.title: Biden Flashed by 'Large, Naked Scottish Man' as His Motorcade Traveled to Glasgow
node.description: The president was in Scotland to meet with world leaders for the U.N.'s climate change conference when the incident occurred.

node.title: 'Shadow Police' Accused of Covering Up Crimes Committed by Border Patrol Agents
node.description: The SBCC alleged that Border Patrol's Critical Incident Investigative Teams may have protected officers from punishments for crimes such as murder, sexual assault, and physical abuse.

node.title: 'Disgraceful, criminal behaviour': Councillors, staff increasingly abused

node.title: Updates: Melbourne Cup race welcomes back spectators

node.title: Watch Live: Biden speaks at news conference as he leaves climate summit

node.title: Lawyer for ‘Rust’ Assistant Director Says Checking Gun Was Not His Job

node.title: Four, the Latest From Jesse Schenker, Opens on Long Island

node.title: Curtis Sliwa tried to bring his cat to vote. It got weirder from there.
node.description: The cat, Gizmo, was denied entrance to the polling site, and Mr. Sliwa fought with election officials over several matters, daring them to arrest him.

node.title: The next Manhattan D.A. will inherit the Trump investigation.
node.description: Alvin Bragg, the Democratic contender, and Thomas Kenniff, his Republican opponent, are competing to lead a high-profile prosecutor’s office.

node.title: The Dangerous Power of Insecure Billionaires
node.description: Somehow, wealth beyond imagining isn’t enough.

node.title: To Cover World War II, These Women Journalists Fought Sexism at Home
node.description: “The Correspondents,” by Judith Mackrell, is a group portrait of six pioneering female war correspondents, and the considerable challenges they faced.

node.title: Investigation Into Britney Spears Conservatorship Will Look Into Her Finances
node.description: A court filing reveals a request for extensive information about the role of the pop star’s former business manager.

node.title: Methane Vs CO2: Which Is the Most Potent Greenhouse Gas As White House Unveils New Pledge

node.title: Greg Abbott Joins GOP Lawmaker's Campaign Targeting Books on Race, Gender in Texas Schools
node.description: The move comes after Texas state Rep. Matt Krause said he was launching a probe into school library books on topics including race, gender identity and sexuality.

node.title: Judge Orders Freeze of Alex Murdaugh's Finances Amid Concerns Jailed Lawyer is Hiding Millions
node.description: The jailed lawyer's finances are being assessed after a prosecuting attorney suggested he could be hiding millions of dollars.

node.title: Boy Shares Wild Texts From His 'QAnon' Mom: 'Do Not Drink Tap Water'
node.description: The video inspired a wave of other children of QAnon believers to share their concerning experiences with family members and how their relationships have become strained.

node.title: Unvaccinated Police Chief Vowed to 'Take All 3' Shots if He Lived Before Dying From COVID
node.description: "He actually said, 'If I get better, I'll take all three, I don't ever want to go through this again,'" Buddy Crabtree's wife said.

node.title: Hertz Says It's Buying 100,000 Teslas, But Elon Musk Tweets 'No Contract Signed'
node.description: "Tesla has far more demand than production, therefore we will only sell cars to Hertz for the same margin as to consumers," Elon Musk tweeted.

node.title: What New York Subway Globes Are Really For
node.description: You may not have noticed the different colored globes outside New York's subway stations while on a busy commute, but they had a special meaning.

node.title: 'Absolutely thrilled': Auckland retailers excited at plan to ease restrictions
node.description: Some Auckland businesses told RNZ they were delighted at the prospect of welcoming back customers next week, and hoped people continued to respect the Covid-19 rules.

node.title: COVID hospitalizations among school kids much higher in U.S. than U.K.
node.description: The most recent statistics comparing the rate of infections per 100,000 in both countries show that for one week in October, the U.S. had over 10 times more hospital admissions for children under 18 than England.

node.title: Christian radio host gets 3 life prison terms for bilking listeners
node.description: "He ruthlessly stole from his clients who trusted him for almost a decade," said the chief of the Tarrant County DA's Elder Financial Fraud team.

node.title: Widespread Coronavirus Infection Found in Iowa Deer, New Study Says

node.title: The Big Question This Thanksgiving: Are You Vaccinated?

node.title: The U.S. says $100 billion a year in climate aid for developing nations is within reach.

node.title: New British Dating Show Shocks Internet With Dramatic Elimination

node.title: U.S. to Launch Effort to Combat Suicide By Gun, Including New Regulations for Sellers

node.title: U.S. Cuts Ethiopia From Trade Program, Issues Sanctions Over Human Rights Violations

node.title: Could re-election as public advocate set Jumaane Williams up for the governor’s race?

node.title: The Board of Elections has a spotty track record. Officials say today is going more smoothly.
node.description: After embarrassing missteps during June’s primary, the Board of Elections said there had not been major disruptions to voting on Tuesday morning.

node.title: A cryptocurrency inspired by ‘Squid Game’ crashes. The industry has questions.

node.title: Is It Possible to Explain How Consciousness Works?

node.title: 9-Year-Old Fatally Stabs 11-Year-Old in Fight Over Nerf Gun

node.title: Only 89 NYC Cops on Leave Over Vaccine Mandate Despite Lawsuit, Union Opposition

node.title: Texas Leads U.S. in Uncounted From 2020 Census With 377K, Simulation Shows

node.title: Ethiopia leader asks citizens to defend government as rebels advance

node.title: The billions set aside in Glasgow to save forests represent a fraction of spending to support fossil fuels.

node.title: Biden pledged $3 billion to help the world adapt to climate change. That’s not as much as it seems.

node.title: What’s at stake? Is it too late to register to vote? Making sense of Election Day.

node.title: The judge presiding over the case has been ‘in this business for 50 years.’

node.description: Both the U.K. minister for the Middle East and North Africa and the U.K.'s ambassador to Israel have apologized formally to Karine Elharrar-Hartstein.

node.title: Boston, Virginia Will Make History Tonight, Electing First Women of Color to Top Roles

node.description: French President Emmanuel Macron said this week that the nuclear submarine deal was "very bad news for the credibility of Australia."

node.title: Kristy Swanson, actress and vaccine skeptic, is hospitalized with Covid.

node.title: How Fentanyl and Meth Took Over America
